Hey Tim, I was lying in bed this morning and the thought occurred to me that a question in the post in-flight abort test news conference that was not asked but perhaps should have been asked is one involving what constitutes a test of THE "WORST case" scenario and a scenario where THE MOST "natural" or "authentic" configuration of the whole-stack vehicle is implemented. Perhaps you would like to ask about this in some future news conference? My idea of what constitutes THE "worst" case scenario and THE "most natural and authentic configuration" is the following:

Have an in-flight abort test where the 1st stage engines are running at full throttle, at the velocity of the test that actually occurred, but where they are not shut down. What happens is, a small explosive charge set just behind the capsule on the 2nd stage (which is fully loaded with fuel and oxidizer) goes off, triggering a second stage explosion. It's at this point that the capsule attempts to escape the stack. Also, the capsule has been kitted out with all the sensors exactly as in the test that was done but everything else about the capsule remains as it would be in normal mission to the ISS (sans people of course :-). There would be no gutting/stripping of the interior of the capsule. And for good measure they would have a normal 2nd stage with a functioning MVAC engine installed.

What say you about these ideas? What I'm trying to get at here is THE worst case scenario within THE most natural vehicle stack & flight profile to the ISS, with the exception of test instrumentation, (and, of course, without people) that is possible.

Dear Everyday Astronaut. That is the question I wrote down during the introductionary part of that press conference, hoping to ask that question to Elon on Tweeter (once I create my account there just for that purpose): "Elon, In the Launch abort demo, it was said, that Dragon Capsule sent a shut down signal to Falcon 9 while executing the abort. Is dragon capsule capable of separating from Dragon 9 even if that signal does not work as intended? (Falcon 9 does not shut down and continues it's ascent?)". That question was triggered by the lack of clarity on the actual process of that demo we saw. I hear throughout the whole press conference and when I almost loose my hope that it will ever get answered, I hear Your question, which is the very last question on that press conference. And that question nails that matter, although it is almost not understood at all at the beginning. But then, You continue to ask to clarify the substance of the question and then You finally get the answer, that Dragon Capsule is capable of separating from Falcon 9 even if Falcon 9 keeps on firing its' engines during the abort. And that is the answer that finished the conference.
Thank You very much for that question and... somehow I wasn't surprised it was You, that asked, and continued to pursue for the answer, for it :)

I am thrilled that the in-flight abort went perfectly, but as far as Starship and Superheavy go I'm not sure Elon has addressed all of the structural issues that might exist. This goes beyond the difficulty of the tank domes. For instance, during re-entry of Starship - when its tanks are mostly empty - what kind of surface pressures will exist on the heat shield surface and what kind of internal tank pressure compensation will be needed to counteract the enormous external windward pressure? Can that kind of compensatory pressure be achieved and yet not blow out the leeward side of the tank? I think  a significant internal reinforcement structure is going to be needed to keep Starship from crumpling like an empty beer can. Even a full beer can distorts under the fingers when held in the hand and squeezed.

It's a shame your question, though you asked it twice wasn't fully answered. Was the abort caused by the shutting down of the engine and the abort system kicking in because the engine had shutdown and the abort system itself detected this or because they had preprogrammed the abort to happen in sequence i.e. Step 1 Engine shutdown, Step 2 abort triggered without the abort system itself aborting but rather a preprogrammed set of events. This answer would have told us whether they tested both the system detecting a problem then aborting or just the abort. Both cases interesting but it would have been nice to know exactly how far the test went
